@graph.headline: Finding Your Average Order Value in Shopify (And Why It Matters)
@graph.description: Learn how to find, calculate, and optimize your Average Order Value (AOV) in Shopify to increase revenue without spending more on customer acquisition.

@graph.name: How to Find Average Order Value in Shopify
@graph.description: Step-by-step guide to locate your AOV in Shopify admin dashboard

step.name: Access Shopify Admin
step.text: Log into your Shopify admin dashboard

step.name: Navigate to Analytics
step.text: Head to Analytics section from your admin dashboard

step.name: Select Reports
step.text: Click on Reports to view your sales data

step.name: View AOV
step.text: Your store's AOV is displayed on the main sales reports dashboard

step.name: Adjust Date Range
step.text: Tweak the date range to analyze AOV over specific periods

@graph.name: How to Calculate Average Order Value Manually
@graph.description: Manual calculation method for AOV using the standard formula

step.name: Gather Sales Data
step.text: Collect your total sales revenue (net sales after discounts, before shipping and taxes)

step.name: Count Orders
step.text: Count the total number of orders for the same period

step.name: Apply Formula
step.text: Divide total sales revenue by total number of orders: AOV = Total Sales Revenue / Total Number of Orders

step.name: Example Calculation
step.text: If your store did $50,000 in sales from 1,000 orders: $50,000 / 1,000 = $50 AOV

mainEntity.name: Which Shopify report is best for getting the raw numbers for my AOV calculation?

acceptedAnswer.text: The 'Sales over time' report in your Shopify Analytics is the gold standard. It gives you the two numbers you need: total sales and the total number of orders for any given period. This is the cleanest source for doing any manual or segmented calculations.

mainEntity.name: Beyond AOV, what other metrics give the best context on customer value?

acceptedAnswer.text: You absolutely have to look at Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) and Purchase Frequency. AOV tells you what a customer spends now, but CLV tells you what they're worth over their entire relationship with your brand. A customer with a slightly lower AOV but a much higher purchase frequency might actually be more valuable in the long run.

mainEntity.name: How does segmenting my customers actually change my AOV insights?

acceptedAnswer.text: Segmenting is everything. A blended, store-wide AOV might be $80. But when you segment, you might find that new customers have an AOV of $60 while returning customers have an AOV of $110. That's not just a data point; it's a massive strategic insight. It tells you that your efforts should focus on turning new customers into repeat buyers, because that's where the real value is.

@graph.name: AOV Related Metrics in Shopify
@graph.description: Comprehensive table of metrics related to Average Order Value and where to find them in Shopify

hasDefinedTerm.name: Average Order Value
hasDefinedTerm.description: The average dollar amount a customer spends every time they place an order on your store over a specific period. Calculated as Total Sales Revenue divided by Total Number of Orders.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Customer Lifetime Value
hasDefinedTerm.description: The total long-term value of a customer, calculated as AOV × Purchase Frequency × Customer Lifespan. Represents the total revenue a customer will generate over their entire relationship with your brand.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Conversion Rate
hasDefinedTerm.description: The percentage of website visitors who complete a desired action, such as making a purchase. One of the big three e-commerce metrics alongside traffic and AOV.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Upselling
hasDefinedTerm.description: A sales technique where customers are persuaded to buy a more expensive version of a product they're considering, such as upgrading to a Pro model.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Cross-selling
hasDefinedTerm.description: A sales technique where customers are offered related or complementary items to their main purchase, such as suggesting a camera lens to someone buying a camera.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Product Bundling
hasDefinedTerm.description: A marketing strategy where related products are grouped together and sold as a single package, usually at a slight discount to increase perceived value.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Buy Now Pay Later
hasDefinedTerm.description: Payment services that allow customers to make purchases and pay for them in installments over time, reducing payment friction for larger purchases.
